comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: news.google.com/newspapers?id=utBaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JJIDA... here's a 1922 Sydney Mail pic of Bona coming to grief somewhere near Long Reef

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Great article! Our vessels curator thinks  the image of BONA also appears in Sydney Sails, it would be great to find the originals. Apparently the BONA in this article is the cutter BONA, as opposed to the schooner BONA (that later became BOOMERANG - confused yet?). The schooner BONA was built in Sydney and taken to Melbourne, while the cutter BONA was racing in Sydney from about 1899. Our yachting expert David thinks there must have been a time in the 1920s when both were in Sydney and the Alberts changed the name of their schooner to BOOMERANG.  (The Alberts also had two BOOMERANGs, one a motor vessel & the other the schooner). Phew!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 56512128@N06
comment._content: This photo is likely to be from the 1926 Pittwater Regatta - PITTWATER CUP. The big yachts are to race for the Pittwater Cup; This handsome trophy has been presented by the treasurer, Mr. C. A. Le Maistre Walker, who is enjoying his first year of office. The course is 16 miles, and H. Nossiter's Utiekah II. is to be on the limit mark of 21min. N. L. II. Griffin's White Wings is oh 24, J. S. Palmer's Aoma 18 J, J. R. Palmer's Brand V.... H. J. Fitzpatrick's Bona 10, and Frank Albert's Rawhiti scr. Examining the handicaps, it certainlylooks as if the race is a gift for Rawhiti, as no penalty- has been imposed on the big green boat for her four recent wins. THE YACHTSMEN. (1926, December 24). Arrow (Sydney, NSW : 1916 - 1933), p. 16. Retrieved from nla.gov.au/nla.news-article103439200

comment.author: 56512128@N06
comment._content:
At Pittwater Online News we're currently reuniting, or trying to, all old images of Pittwater Regattas from both ANMM and State Library of NSW - it's wonderful that you are sharing these - people really enjoy these pages and it is bringing what some deem History 'back to life'. Each month we have a theme and in November 2013 it is Pittwater Regattas with each week seeing one year from the decades 1900 to 1940 selected. Shall try and get back here early December to place links for all those others who love our Maritime heritage and History
Thank you very much ANMM and Quasymody for your efforts too!
